children.name: An increase in an amount or number
increase
examples: sự tăng thêm
increase in
▪ There will be no increase in student enrolments this year.
▪ an increase in consumer spending
increase of 10/20/50% etc
▪ There was an increase of about 17% in the urban population between 1910 and 1920.
a 10%/12% etc increase
▪ Improved airline service led to an 18.7% increase in tourists to Africa last year.

children.name: rise
children.definition: an increase in numbers, level, population, or temperature:
examples: sự tăng lên
rise in
▪ The committee will investigate the rise in the number of hospital admissions.
▪ This year a disappointingly small rise in pass rates.
rise of
▪ Global warming is responsible for a rise of 7 degrees Celsius in just over 50 years.

children.name: growth
children.definition: an increase in amount, quantity, population etc:
examples: sự tăng trưởng
economic/population etc growth
▪ There is a great deal of uncertainty about the world’s population growth.
▪ favorable signs of economic growth
▪ DIY outlets reported sales growth of 1.8%.
growth in
▪ The US portion of the Internet is experiencing rapid growth in the number of networks connected to it.
growth of
▪ the astonishing growth of on-line trading

children.name: build-up
children.definition: agradualincrease in somethingharmfulorbad:

children.name: sự tăng cường
examples: ▪ This could signal the biggest military build-up since the Cold War.

children.name: build-up of
examples: ▪ The changing world climate is probably due to a build-up of harmful gases such as carbon dioxide.

children.name: upturn
children.definition: an increase in the amount of trade done by a country, company etc after a period of time when it was not increasing:
examples: ▪ Only in the last two years have we seen signs of an economic upturn.

children.name: upturn in
examples: ▪ The upturn in aviation traffic will help lift demand for commercial aircraft.

children.name: increase
children.definition: to become larger in number, amount, price, value etc:

children.name: tăng lên
examples: ▪ Gradually the noise and traffic increased as they approached the city.
▪ Hormone levels increase throughout pregnancy.
▪ The use of mobile phones has increased enormously over the past two years.
▪ Revenue and profits have increased dramatically this year.

children.name: increase by 10%/$100/2 million etc
examples: ▪ The price of cigarettes has increased by 30% in the last two years.

children.name: increase to to reach a total of $1000 etc
examples: ▪ Wind speeds are expected to increase to 60 mph.
▪ The number of high school students using LSD has increased to its highest level since 1986.

children.name: increase from £300/1 million etc to £400/1.5 million etc
examples: ▪ Health care costs increased from £1.9 billion in 2000 to £4 billion in 2001.

children.name: increase in number/value etc
examples: ▪ Major league clubs have increased in number from 26 to 28.

children.name: go up/ rise
children.definition: go up/rise  to increase - use this about numbers, prices, or temperatures etc, but also about the level or standard of something:

children.name: tăng lên
examples: ▪ The price of petrol is going up again, for the third time this year.
▪ The jobless rate hit 9.3% last month, after rising for four months in a row.
▪ With more and more cars on the road, pollution levels are rising steadily.
▪ You’ll need about £10, if the rail fare’s gone up again, which I expect it has.

children.name: go up/rise by 10%/$500 etcbecome 10% etc greater
examples: ▪ Personal computer sales rose by 70% in the run-up to Christmas.

children.name: go up/rise to
examples: ▪ By mid-day, the temperature had already risen to 40 degrees.

children.name: go up/rise from £300/1 million etc to £400/2 million etc
examples: ▪ The average price of a loaf of bread has gone up from 25p to 60p.

children.name: grow
children.definition: to increasegraduallyover a period of time - use this about numbers or amounts, or about a total amount ofbusiness activity or trade:

children.name: tăng trưởng
examples: ▪ China’s economic output continues to grow at a remarkable annual rate.
▪ Demand for new cars is growing rapidly.
▪ The number of openly gay rock musicians has grown steadily in recent years, and shows no signs of abating.

children.name: grow by 10%/5000 etc become 10% etc greater
examples: ▪ Profits in the military aircraft business grew by 28% to a record $905 million.

children.name: grow to
examples: ▪ The personnel team has grown to 6,700 full-time employees from just 900 in 2000.

children.name: climb
children.definition: if the temperature, prices, profits etc climb, they increase until they reach a very high level:
examples: ▪ Demand for goods grew and imports climbed steadily.

children.name: climb to
examples: ▪ The original estimate of $500 million has now climbed to a staggering $1300 million.
▪ Temperatures are expected to climb to record levels this weekend.

children.name: gain
children.definition: if something or someone gains speed, weight, or height, their speed, weight, or height increases:
examples: ▪ The train rolled forward, gaining speed rapidly.
▪ A new-born baby will gain weight at around one ounce per day.
▪ The four men told the inquiry they did not know why the plane failed to gain height after it took off.

children.name: escalate
children.definition: to increase to a high level - use this about things you do not want to increase such as prices, crimes etc:
examples: ▪ Gas prices are expected to continue to escalate in the short term.
▪ Staff saw costs escalating and sales slumping as the effect of the recession hit the company.

children.name: escalate to
examples: ▪ The cost of the new building has escalated to a worrying level.

children.name: escalate sharply/dramatically
examples: ▪ The number of attacks on foreign aid workers has escalated dramatically.

children.name: pick up
children.definition: if trade, business, or work picks up, the amount of it that is available increases after it has been at a level that is too low:
examples: ▪ Their shop was losing money, but they carried on in the hope that business would pick up soon.
▪ At present the hotel is almost empty, but I’m sure things will start to pick up in the spring.

children.name: widen
children.definition: if a difference between two amounts widens, or the range of things available widens, it increases:
examples: ▪ The range of university courses available has widened tremendously in recent years.
▪ The gap between the incomes of two-carer families and lone mothers with children has widened.

children.name: be on the increase
children.definition: if something bad such as a problem or illness is on the increase, it is happening more and more frequently:
examples: ▪ Juvenile crime is on the increase in most parts of the country.
▪ Homelessness has been on the increase for a long time.

children.name: be on the increase among
examples: ▪ What is particularly alarming is that bullying is on the increase among even very young primary children.

children.name: intensify
children.definition: if an effort or an activity such as fighting intensifies, it increases so that more people do it or the people already doing it use more effort:
examples: ▪ The fighting intensified and spread through the city.
▪ As the season intensifies, quarterback Young will need to work on his fitness.
▪ The controversy is only expected to intensify.

children.name: expand
children.definition: if trade or a business activity expands, it increases:
examples: ▪ Trade between developing countries and industrialized countries is beginning to expand.
▪ The business was growing rapidly and beginning to expand abroad.
expansion/ɪkˈspænʃən/ [uncountable noun]
▪ the continued expansion of the Chinese economy
economic expansion
▪ a period of rapid economic expansion

children.name: build up
children.definition: if the number or amount of something builds up, it increases gradually so that there is much more than there was before:
examples: ▪ Traffic is building up on the southern exit of the motorway.
▪ A huge backlog of work had built up during my absence.

children.name: when numbers or amounts are increasing
increasing
examples: ▪ An increasing number of Australians see the link to the British monarchy as irrelevant.
▪ An increasing percentage of American property owners are taking their houses off the market.

children.name: ever-increasingincreasing all the time
examples: ▪ Ever-increasing numbers of science teachers are leaving their jobs to work in industry.
▪ Ever-increasing amounts of land were brought under cultivation.

children.name: rising
children.definition: increasing - use this about prices, numbers etc or about the level or standard of something:
examples: ▪ Rising fuel costs have forced many airlines to put up the price of air tickets.
▪ Le Shuttle competes with an ever-rising number of ferries for the busy Channel crossing.

children.name: ▪ the rising rate of smoking among teenagers when problems increase and become more serious
examples: ▪ We are entering a period of slow economic growth and rising unemployment.

children.name: growing
children.definition: gradually increasing:
examples: ▪ An economic miracle is needed if Bangladesh is to feed its huge and growing population.
▪ Zena is one of a small but rapidly growing number of motorists choosing to buy a car over the Web.
▪ Garbage collection is a growth industry, thanks to growing volumes of garbage -- up 2-3% a year.

children.name: mounting
children.definition: a mounting price or number is increasing and causes problems:
examples: ▪ He struggled on in the face of mounting debts,
▪ What are the reasons for mounting unemployment in the Arab countries?
▪ Another year of mounting losses proved too much for Pepperdine’s basketball coach.

children.name: escalating
children.definition: escalating prices, problems etc are increasing quickly and making a situation worse than it was before:
examples: ▪ Investors in the Sports Stadium project are worried by escalating construction costs.

children.name: ▪ rapidly escalating house prices
examples: ▪ Twenty percent of the workforce are experiencing escalating stress levels.

children.name: multiply
children.definition: to increase greatly in number:
examples: ▪ Since they started borrowing money, their problems have multiplied.
▪ The number of settlements multiplied enormously.
▪ The insects multiply rapidly during hot, dry summers.

children.name: double
children.definition: to become twice as much or twice as many:

children.name: tăng gấp đôi
examples: ▪ Welfare spending will nearly double by the year 2002.

children.name: double to
examples: ▪ The number of female bank managers doubled from 104 to 208.

children.name: double in size/value
examples: ▪ In those thirty years, San Francisco doubled in size.

children.name: triplealso treble British
children.definition: to become three times as much or three times as many:
examples: ▪ The number of senior citizens living in poverty has trebled in the last three years.
▪ The party’s majority in Congress tripled as a result of the election.

children.name: triple in size/value
examples: ▪ The shares have trebled in value since trading resumed on Wednesday.

children.name: quadruple
children.definition: to become four times as much or four times as many:
examples: ▪ In ten years, homicide rates tripled and suicide rates quadrupled.

children.name: quadruple to
examples: ▪ By the end of 1973, the price of oil had quadrupled to $11.65 a gallon.

children.name: proliferate
children.definition: if something proliferates, it increases very quickly, and becomes more common:
examples: ▪ The HIV virus is able to proliferate at an astonishing rate.
▪ Child pornography is proliferating due to the increased use of computer chat rooms.
proliferation/prəˌlɪfəˈreɪʃən/ [uncountable noun]
proliferate of
▪ the rapid proliferation of on-line catalogues

children.name: snowball
children.definition: to increase in number, at first slowly and then faster and faster:
examples: ▪ Unemployment snowballed at the beginning of the 1980s.
▪ Things hadn’t exactly been going our way, but after the first defeat, everything sort of snowballed.

children.name: shoot up
children.definition: if something such as a price, number, or temperature shoots up, it increasesquicklyandsuddenly:

children.name: tăng nhanh, tăng đột ngột
examples: ▪ As long as mortgage rates do not shoot up, property should remain a good investment.

children.name: shoot up to
examples: ▪ US exports to Mexico have already shot up to 130% since 1985.
▪ A year ago the magazine had a circulation of 150,000, but since then that figure has shot up to an astonishing 2 million.

children.name: soar
children.definition: to increase quickly to a high level:
examples: soar into
▪ Temperatures soared into the nineties.
▪ The cost of a business Website can soar into millions of dollars.
soar to
▪ Last year, the drugs haul soared to 130,00 tablets.
▪ The death toll soars to 376 in Chicago from last week’s heat wave.
soar by 40%/£300/1 million etc
▪ In the first year of peace, Lebanon’s GDP soared by almost 40%.
soaring[adjective only before noun]
▪ a plan to tackle soaring crime rates
▪ Industrial growth has brought power cuts, clogged roads and soaring property prices.

children.name: rocket
children.definition: alsoskyrocket  if costs, prices, profits, sales etc rocket, they increase very quickly to a very high level:
examples: ▪ Interest rates have skyrocketed as credit has become scarce.
▪ Why has the dollar rocketed against the yen in particular?
rocket to
▪ Gold prices rocketed to their highest level since 1983.
rocketing/skyrocketing[adjective only before noun]
▪ the skyrocketing cost of land

children.name: go through the roof
children.definition: if prices go through the roof, they increase to an extremely high level:
examples: ▪ Following news of increased profits, the company’s share price went through the roof.
▪ Sales of Ray-Ban sunglasses went through the roof after Tom Cruise wore them in ‘Risky Business’.

children.name: spiral
children.definition: if a debt or the cost of something spirals, it increases very quickly and uncontrollably:
examples: ▪ Since the project started five years ago, costs have spiralled.
▪ With inflation spiralling out of control, the country was close to economic collapse.

children.name: take off
children.definition: if numbers or prices take off, they begin to increase quickly after a long period when they did not increase:
examples: ▪ With the introduction of user-friendly software, home computer sales suddenly took off.
▪ Internet shopping will really take off when people become convinced that it is secure.

children.name: to increase by gradually adding more
accumulate
children.definition: to increase gradually in number or amount until there is a large quantity in one place:
examples: ▪ An army of 1650 plows and 2000 workers will be out this afternoon as snow begins to accumulate.
▪ Sand had accumulated at the mouth of the river and formed a bank which boats could not pass.
▪ Over a period of years, the drug will accumulate in the body and damage the nervous system.

children.name: build up
children.definition: if something such as a substance or a force builds up somewhere, it increases gradually as more of it is added or more of it appears:
examples: ▪ Deposits of lime will stick to the surface and build up over the years.
▪ As the temperature rises, the pressure builds up inside the chamber.
▪ Fertilizers can contain salts that build up in the soil.

children.name: pile up
children.definition: if something such as work or debt piles up, it increases as more is added to it until there is a large quantity of it:
examples: ▪ The work just keeps on piling up and makes me want to scream.
▪ As her debts piled up, she came close to a nervous breakdown.

children.name: mount up
children.definition: if prices, costs, debts etc mount up, they increase as more is added over a period of time, and cause more and more problems:
examples: ▪ She finally had to go back to work to pay the bills that were mounting up.
▪ The national debt has mounted up, growing to $1 trillion since Clinton took office.

children.name: collect
children.definition: if something such as a liquid collects somewhere, it goes to that place and the amount there gradually increases:

children.name: ▪ As the tide came in, water collected to form small pools among the rocks.collect on/inside/behind etc
examples: ▪ Rain collecting at the tip of the rock has formed huge icicles.
▪ If condensation collects on the inside of the window, wipe it off with a clean cloth.

children.name: gather
children.definition: if a substance such as dirt, snow etc gathers somewhere, more and more of it appears in that place and stays there:
examples: ▪ There were gaps between the floorboards where dust and bits of grime had gathered.

children.name: gather on/around/behind etc
examples: ▪ Snow gathered thickly in the folds of their clothes.
▪ Harry was afraid. Sweat gathered on his upper lip.

children.name: to make a number or amount increase
increase
examples: ▪ High alcohol consumption increases the risk of liver disease.
▪ The Clean Air Act would increase the cost of electric power in the Midwest.
▪ The party aims to increase the number of women elected to Congress.
▪ We reduced the size of the magazine because we didn’t want to increase the price.
increase something to
▪ The company has increased its workforce to 1,500 employees
increase something by 20%/$400/1 million etc
▪ a program to increase output by 14%

children.name: raise
children.definition: if someone raises raises a tax, price, temperature etc, they increase it:
examples: ▪ The president should take the necessary steps of raising taxes and cutting public spending.
▪ All the major airlines have raised their fares.

children.name: raise something to $300/40C/200 etc
examples: ▪ The retirement age has been raised to 65 for both men and women.

children.name: put up
children.definition: if someone puts up the cost or price of something, they increase it:
examples: ▪ They’ve put up the price of petrol again.
▪ A solicitor can advise whether the landlord has a right to put the rent up.
▪ This used to be quite a cheap restaurant but they’ve put their prices up since the last time I came here.

children.name: jack up
children.definition: to increase prices or amounts by a large amount, especially when this seems unreasonable:
examples: jack something up
▪ I guess they must jack the price up in the summer, then mark it down in the winter.
jack up something
▪ a proposal that would have jacked up taxi fares by as much as 30%

children.name: push up/drive up/force up
children.definition: to make something increase - use this about things you would prefer to keep low, such as costs and prices:

children.name: push/drive/force up something
examples: ▪ An expansion of the weapons research program is sure to drive up defence costs.
▪ In recent years, increased demand has forced up the price of copper on world markets.

children.name: push/force/drive something up
examples: ▪ Office vacancy rates have reached a low, pushing rents up sharply for office and industrial space.

children.name: boost
children.definition: to increase something such as production, sales, or wages because they are not as high as you want them to be:
examples: ▪ The plan was meant to boost agricultural production.
▪ The multi-million dollar ad campaign has failed to boost sales.
▪ Greater consumer access to the Internet has boosted electronic retailing.

children.name: double/triple/quadruple
children.definition: to increase a number or amount by two, three, or four times:
examples: ▪ The company has quadrupled Sonia’s salary in just three years in recognition of her achievements.
▪ The government doubled the sales tax on cigarettes from 20% to 40%.

children.name: maximizealsomaximiseBritish
children.definition: to make something such as profit, power, or productivity increase to the highest level that you can achieve:
examples: ▪ The bank’s function is to maximize profits, and that requires some risk-taking.
▪ To maximise power output, solar panels are placed on the highest part of the building.

children.name: to increase by adding another number or amount
add to
children.definition: if achangeto something, especially an improvement, adds to its cost, price, value, or amount, it causes the cost, price, value, or amount to increase:

children.name: làm tăng thêm, làm gia tăng
examples: ▪ Gardens that have been substantially improved will add to the value of your property.
▪ New high-quality printing technology added $1,000 to the retail price of the computer.
▪ The diversion added another hour to our journey.

children.name: augment
children.definition: to increase and improve the strength, value, effectiveness etc of something:
examples: ▪ The cream contains ingredients that augment the skin’s natural healing processes.
▪ We pay performance bonuses that augment your annual salary.

children.name: put 10p/20p etc on
children.definition: if something such as a new tax or increased production cost puts 10p/20p etc on the price of something, it causes the price to increase by that much:
examples: ▪ The new tax puts 20 pence on the price of a pack of cigarettes.
▪ The increased cost of imported wheat will put 5p on the price of a loaf of bread.

children.name: to increase the amount of st you do
increase
examples: ▪ We must increase public awareness of the health risks associated with sunbathing.
▪ The government is increasing pressure on drug-traffickers.
▪ The imposition of martial law will only increase violence and repression.

children.name: step up
children.definition: to increase your efforts or activities, especially in order to improve a situation that is not as good as you want it to be:

children.name: step up something
examples: ▪ The US government stepped up its war against terrorism.
▪ The police presence is to be stepped up at this year’s carnival.

children.name: step it upmake a greater effort to achieve something
examples: ▪ It’s good we were able to step it up at the end of the game.

children.name: expand
children.definition: to increase something so that it covers a wider area or range of activities:
examples: ▪ Dr. Martin also helped expand housing opportunities for people with AIDs.
▪ The agency hopes to expand coverage of new musical talent on its Internet site.

children.name: expand something to something
examples: ▪ They fund programs that expand health benefits to wider segments of the community.

children.name: broaden
children.definition: to increase something such as knowledge, experience, or your range of activities:
examples: ▪ At Missouri, Wright broadened his experience by working on a local newspaper.
▪ The library is installing new technology to broaden access to its huge store of information.
▪ The company has broadened its product range in the US.

children.name: extend
children.definition: to increase something such as your influence or control over something:
examples: ▪ The US government is still trying to extend its influence over European politics.
▪ We can extend our effectiveness enormously by the use of up-to-date technology.
▪ Time Warner recently extended its reach to the world’s biggest music business.

children.name: intensify
children.definition: to increase activities or efforts, especially against an enemy or someone who opposes you:
examples: ▪ In the run-up to the election, terrorists have intensified their activities.
▪ China is intensifying efforts to fight crime.
▪ We have no choice but to intensify the strike campaign.
▪ The latest merger will intensify competition among defense companies.
intensification/ɪnˌtensɪfɪˈkeɪʃən, ɪnˌtensəfɪˈkeɪʃən/ [uncountable noun]
intensify of
▪ The statement signals an intensification of the bloody feud between opposing guerrilla factions.

children.name: to turn or push a button to increase st
turn up
children.definition: turn up the radio/television/heat etc to increase the amount ofsoundcoming out of a radio, television etc or the amount ofheatcoming from a heater, by turning or pushing a button:
examples: tăng, bật to
turn something up
▪ Hey, turn this up for a second, I like this song.
▪ Would you mind turning the heat up?
turn up something
▪ We hooked up my stereo and turned up the volume as loud as it would go.
▪ Is the sound turned up too loud for you?

children.name: an increase in an amount of money
increase
children.definition: tax/fare/price etc increase
examples: ▪ There could be fare increases of up to 10%.
▪ A spokesman for the airline said that much of the cost increase was caused by tightening of security.
increase in
▪ a 12% increase in phone charges
a 50%/30% etc increase
▪ a 50% increase in the city’s health budget

children.name: gain
children.definition: an increase in an amount of money, that brings an advantage to someone:
examples: ▪ The share price ended the year with a 60% gain.

children.name: gain in
examples: ▪ The morning’s gains in US stocks fell sharply.

children.name: gain of
examples: ▪ The Nikkei average experienced a gain of 140.19 points on Friday.

children.name: rise
children.definition: an increase in costs, prices, taxes, or rent:

children.name: rent/price/tax etc rise
examples: ▪ Tenants face a 60% rent rise.
▪ The prime minister is considering substantial tax rises.

children.name: rise in
examples: ▪ The pension will increase in line with the rise in prices.

children.name: riseBritish /raiseAmerican
children.definition: /raɪz, reɪz/  an increase in the amount of money you are paid for your work:
examples: ▪ He received loud applause when he told the crowd that low wage-earners deserve a raise.
▪ IT specialists rang up an average pay rise of 312% last year.

children.name: give somebody a rise
examples: ▪ The State Government simply can’t afford to give all teachers a raise.

children.name: hike
children.definition: a sudden increase in something such as prices, wages, or taxes:
examples: ▪ Big gasoline hikes are expected in April.

children.name: tax/price/wage etc hike
examples: ▪ Pilots will get an 11% pay hike over four years.
▪ Opponents argued the sales-tax hike was unfair.

children.name: hike in
examples: ▪ Trade Unions are proposing a hike in the minimum wage.

children.name: increment
children.definition: an amount that is added regularly to someone’s pay every year, every six months etc:
examples: ▪ The contract includes a salary increment every six months.
▪ Automatic pay increments based on length of service will be abolished.

children.name: leap
children.definition: a sudden large increase in the amount or number of something -- use this especially about business costs, prices, activities etc:
examples: ▪ Coffee and orange juice prices made their biggest leaps on Friday.
leap in
▪ Borrowers have been warned to expect another leap in bank interest rates.
▪ Gold shares gained following a leap in the price of gold.
by leaps and boundsuse this to emphasize how quickly something is increasing
▪ I can see the Internet business growing by leaps and bounds. leap [intransitive verb]
▪ Shares leapt about 5% to $32.375.

children.name: explosion
children.definition: a very sudden and very large increase in population, in an activity, or in the numbers of something:
examples: ▪ We live in the century of population explosion, with the world’s population doubling at least every 25 years.
▪ These people are full of hope. An economic explosion is underway in their country.

children.name: explosion of
examples: ▪ The company cannot meet demand, and has seen an explosion of customer complaints.
▪ No-one can say where the amazing explosion of digital services will take us.

children.name: explosion in
examples: ▪ Officials insist the case is unrelated to the explosion in homicide rates among teenager s.

children.name: boom
children.definition: a sudden large increase in something such as trade, economic success, or a particular area of activity:
examples: ▪ The IT market is growing, thanks to the Internet boom.
boom in
▪ the boom in cellular phone ownership
▪ a record-breaking boom in tourism
economic booma period of economic and financial success
▪ Canada enjoyed a real economic boom in the postwar years.
property/productivity spending etc boom
▪ Motorola is one of the leaders in the global technology boom.
▪ The impact of the property boom was first felt in the financial markets.
baby booma period of time when many more babies are born
▪ A more pressing problem is Mexico’s dramatic baby boom.
boom[intransitive verb]
▪ Cellnet has 800,000 subscribers, and business is booming.
▪ Tourism boomed here in the late 1990s.

children.name: surge
children.definition: a sudden increase in something such as demand, profit, interest etc:
examples: surge in
▪ Last year there was a surge in the company’s profits to $122m.
▪ a 31% surge in divorce rates
▪ Stores are expecting a surge in demand as Christmas approaches.
▪ Her books enjoyed a huge surge in popularity in the mid-1980s.
surge of
▪ The unexpected surge of voters to the polls has surprised even opposition parties. surge [transitive verb]
▪ Orders from customers in the Far East have surged.
surge to
▪ By 2006, the liver transplant figure is likely to surge to at least 4.3 million.
